channel.title: What is so bad about Marijuana?
channel.description: I always see people dissing marijuana. I don't understand what is so bad about it. I understand why they diss stuff like cigarettes, and acid and stuff, but why weed? I have been smoking since 8th grade, and I have never run into any health/social problems because of it. I always see people saying its "stupid" and "ruins your life" "youll die from it"... but really, you dont. I ask people why its so bad and they say "cuz its illegal it must be bad duh!". The real reason they don't legalize it anyway is because it would ruin the economy.

item.title: What is so bad about Marijuana?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

bowserjr2:

it will take more than a month with no use before tetrahydrocannabinol will go out your body. You can get psychosis and other psychic damage.

You’re a little confused. delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol does NOT stay in your body for months. It is metabolised fairly quickly to 11-hydroxy-thc (amongst other active metabolites) and then those are further broken down into inactive metabolites which are stored in fat cells. They no longer have any psychoactive effect on the human body, they do however provide a way for people to tell if you’ve smoked recently (piss tests/ blood tests etc).

Pretty much every chemical you consume is broken down this way and has some form of inactive metabolite that stays in your body for some amount of time (usually a lot shorter, but it makes no difference)

EDIT: Anotehr example of the wonders that is in vivo metabolism: when one smokes tobacco (or ingests nicotine in any other way) a primary metabolite of that process is cotinine, which is detectable in the body for days after the cigarette was smokes - dosen’t stop cravings though, does it? Metabolites are not the same as the drug that was consumed.

TLDR:
11-nor-9-carboxy-thc, one of the long half-life secondary metabolites has NO PSYCHOACTIVE EFFECT. Once you are not stoned anymore, you are not stoned anymore.

Read full topic
item.source: What is so bad about Marijuana?

item.title: What is so bad about Marijuana?
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

Cheese_Police:

You don’t are an expert on English, either.

I assume it’s his second language. He is from Norway.

[quote=“bowserjr2, post:40, topic:262441”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=346575.msg2685519#msg2685519 date=1235658957]

You can be influence by drugs long after you have quit using it, and by not using it for a while. (If you use/have used drugs)

Sure, I’ve been influenced positively by drugs for many months after usage. Any profound experience will have long lasting mental effects (losing your virginity, your first stage performance, passing your exams being examples of non chemically induced similar experiences)

If you’re suggesting that I’m not sober enough to drive or use matches long after I last consumed a chemical though, then your knowledge of chemistry is severely lacking.
[/quote]
You are not drunk I mean, but if you use cannibis(That is marijuana made of right?) much it will take more than a month with no use before tetrahydrocannabinol will go out your body. You can get psychosis and other psychic damage.

And you lose some dexterities by using cannabis and some time after that, don’t know how long, since I don’t are an expert on drugs.[/quote]

The fact that your fat stores it doesn’t mean much. It’s not even psychoactive anymore. I work out often and play sports, I don’t experience anything bad from marijuana still being in my fat cells.

“You can get psychosis and other psychic damage.”
This isn’t proven. It’s only known to make pre-existing cases of mental disorders worse. If you are mentally healthy there’s not much to worry about. Unless you just don’t know about your “pre-existing” mental disorder.

Lose dexterity? Maybe if you smoke too much and you’re burnt out. This is just temporary.

Read full topic

If you’re suggesting that I’m not sober enough to drive or use matches long after I last consumed a chemical though, then your knowledge of chemistry is severely lacking.[/quote]
You are not drunk I mean, but if you use cannibis(That is marijuana made of right?) much it will take more than a month with no use before tetrahydrocannabinol will go out your body. You can get psychosis and other psychic damage.

And you lose some dexterities by using cannabis and some time after that, don’t know how long, since I don’t are an expert on drugs.

item.title: What is so bad about Marijuana?
item.dc:creator: @bowserjr2 Bowser jr
item.description:
@bowserjr2 wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:37, topic:262441”][quote author=bowserjr2 link=topic=346575.msg2684172#msg2684172 date=1235570470]
According to Norwegian statistics (I bet is it much the same in US) the worst drivers are from 18-25 years old boys so people begin to be a little smarter after that.
The last one, by using drugs you don’t think about the consequences by Theft, Arson and dangerous driving.(Also have something with your age of course).
[/quote]

I’m not in the US, I’m in the UK. I fully agree that 18-25 year olds are more likely to be worse drivers than older people, due to showing off & simple lack of experience. However I fail to see what that has to do with drugs. I have never stolen, set fire to property that wasn’t mine or driven dangerously (or AT ALL) while under the influence of anything. So you’re spouting irrelevance.[/quote]
You can be influence by drugs long after you have quit using it, and by not using it for a while. (If you use/have used drugs)

EDIT: And because what you said was so dumb, one of the items on that list was dangerous driving. If you’ll explain your theory on how the recreational, occaisional use of drugs causes one to practise wheelies and endos on a public highway, I’d be happy to debunk it.[/quote]

item.title: What is so bad about Marijuana?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

I have never stolen for drug money, what a ridiculous notion. The only two crimes on that list that were drug related are the possesion of a control substance, which… well, duh.

The others all happened when sober, and one when I was far too young to have found drugs yet.

I doubt I will be much smarter in 4 years tbh, I think base intelligence pretty much peaks after puberty.

EDIT: And because what you said was so dumb, one of the items on that list was dangerous driving. If you’ll explain your theory on how the recreational, occaisional use of drugs causes one to practise wheelies and endos on a public highway, I’d be happy to debunk it.

item.title: What is so bad about Marijuana?
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

[quote=“bowserjr2, post:32, topic:262441”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=346575.msg2682365#msg2682365 date=1235443180]
It’s funny that you say drug using friends will destroy your life, the drug using friends I’ve had have been my closest and best friends. Negative stereotypes are bad, yoh.

If you don’t want to use drugs, it’s always within your power to say no, whoever your friends are, jeez.
[/quote]
Yes if your friends respect your no, but not all can say no every time someone ask them.
Ok, people with drugs don’t destroy you, but you should not get someone to start, not give them their first drugs.

And sorry for saying this, but you will get problem because of your drugs and alcohol.

Like you write in the crime tread:

Lol, this is ridiculous. But I’ll play.

Possession of a Controlled Substance
Possession of a Controlled Substance with Intent to Supply
Theft
UNDERAGED DRINKING DOES NOT EXIST IN THE UK MUHAHAHA SUCK ON THAT
Speeding
Dangerous Driving
Arson

To add a twist to the tale, only 2 of these was I caught for. But which?

ps squiggylo is a liar or a rapist and i can’t work out which

You are crazy, stop with drugs and alcohol, even worse is it if you steal to get money for drugs and alcohol.
Hopefully you will be a little smarter when you are 25.[/quote]

When did he say he steals for drug money?

Don’t make assumptions about people’s lives because you really don’t know shit. You remind me of ruler.

jme:

But if you are against harder drugs, you don’t have to do them. If someone is worried about smoking weed because it can lead to harder drugs, just remember only you can decide what you put into your body.

Problem is you lose control, I’am sure many that use drugs have said: “I would never start with drugs”, but with friend that use it and you are drunk you get easier convinced.
And you start with harder drugs, best way to avoid it is to NEVER start not even testing, and watch out for people that will destroy your life.

item.title: What is so bad about Marijuana?
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:24, topic:262441”]But it’s common sence, you get bored of the high weed gives you, so you think “hey, fuck it, lets go for something more…”
i know i did, i am not regretting it! Just stating…[/quote]

A large part of that also comes from the lies they spread about “softer” drugs, imo.

“Hey, pot didn’t do any of those bad things the school told me it would, I bet they lied about the dangers of MDMA/coke/heroin too”

Read full topic
item.source: What is so bad about Marijuana?

item.title: What is so bad about Marijuana?
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:24, topic:262441”]But it’s common sence, you get bored of the high weed gives you, so you think “hey, fuck it, lets go for something more…”
i know i did, i am not regretting it! Just stating…[/quote]

I’m not going to deny that. You’re right. I was against most hard drugs. Before I started smoking pot, I liked the idea of shrooms from what I had read about them, but I was worried to do them (plus I didn’t have a connection for them) because of the way I’ve seen people get on them. Forcing themselves to puke so that they don’t get higher, wishing they were dead so that they wouldn’t have to endure a few more hours of the mental state they were in. As I smoked pot for a while after, I felt I was ready. I developed a huge interest in drugs, I find them absolutely fascinating. I used to read about every drug I could think of for hours simply because I was interested. I gradually became more open to doing the drugs I was reading about.

Now I’ll do a hard drug, and have a fun time. But they make me appreciate marijuana even more. It’s so easy, so reliable. And despite having a good time on the harder drugs, I always feel that I got my little fun in and that I don’t need to repeat the experience, or at least for a long time.

But if you are against harder drugs, you don’t have to do them. If someone is worried about smoking weed because it can lead to harder drugs, just remember only you can decide what you put into your body.

Read full topic

item.source: What is so bad about Marijuana?

item.title: What is so bad about Marijuana?
item.dc:creator: @jme jme
item.description:
@jme wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:22, topic:262441”][quote author=jme link=topic=346575.msg2673125#msg2673125 date=1234910015]

One problem with it is people that use it easy go over on harder things like LSD and Heroin.

No it doesn’t. That’s like saying drinking coffee makes you try harder drugs like meth.
[/quote]

No he is right, smoking weed is an entry to harder drugs, it is a proven fact(something like 90% try harder drugs after weed)!

But really, alcohol is the entry drug…[/quote]

Where did you get that statistic?

Most pot smokers I know are violently opposed to harder drugs, other then my dealers and a few close friends.

"There is no conclusive evidence that the drug effects of marijuana are causally linked to the subsequent abuse of other illicit drugs."

Source: Janet E. Joy, Stanley J. Watson, Jr., and John A Benson, Jr., “Marijuana and Medicine: Assessing the Science Base,” Division of Neuroscience and Behavioral Research, Institute of Medicine (Washington, DC: National Academy Press, 1999).

“Our key findings were that 1) there are no unique factors distinguishing the gateway sequence and the reverse sequence — that is, the sequence is opportunistic; 2) the gateway sequence and the reverse sequence have the same prognostic accuracy; and 3) a sizable proportion of substance users begin regular consumption with an illicit drug. These results, considered in the aggregate, indicate that the gateway sequence is not an invariant pathway and, when manifest, is not related to specific risk factors and does not have prognostic utility. The results of this study as well as other studies demonstrate that abusable drugs occupy neither a specific place in a hierarchy nor a discrete position in a temporal sequence. These latter presumptions of the gateway hypothesis constitute what Whitehead referred to as the ‘fallacy of misplaced connectedness,’ namely, asserting ‘assumptions about categories that do not correspond with the empirical world.’”

Source: Tarter, Ralph E., PhD, Vanyukov, Michael, PhD, Kirisci, Levent, PhD, Reynolds, Maureen, PhD, Clark, Duncan B., MD, PhD, “Predictors of Marijuana Use in Adolescents Before and After Licit Drug Use: Examination of the Gateway Hypothesis,” American Journal of Psychiatry, Vol. 63, No. 12, December 2006, p. 2139.

“The gateway hypothesis holds that abusable drugs occupy distinct ranks in a hierarchy as well as definite positions in a temporal sequence. Accordingly, substance use is theorized to progress through a sequence of stages, beginning with legal, socially acceptable compounds that are low in the hierarchy, followed by use of illegal ‘soft’ and later ‘hard’ drugs ranked higher in the hierarchy. One of the main findings of this study is that there is a high rate of nonconformance with this temporal order. In a neighborhood where there is high drug availability, youths who have low parental supervision are likely to regularly consume marijuana before alcohol and/or tobacco. Consumption of marijuana prior to use of licit drugs thus appears to be related to contextual factors rather than to any unique characteristics of the individual. Moreover, this reverse pattern is not rare; it was observed in over 20% of our sample.”

Source: Tarter, Ralph E., PhD, Vanyukov, Michael, PhD, Kirisci, Levent, PhD, Reynolds, Maureen, PhD, Clark, Duncan B., MD, PhD, “Predictors of Marijuana Use in Adolescents Before and After Licit Drug Use: Examination of the Gateway Hypothesis,” American Journal of Psychiatry, Vol. 63, No. 12, December 2006, p. 2138.

“The results of this study suggest that general behavioral deviancy and not specific risk factors accounts for illicit drug use. When illicit drug use occurs first, it is very likely due to the opportunity afforded by the neighborhood environment in context of low parental supervision. The probability and rate of development of a diagnosis of marijuana use disorder and alcohol use disorder were the same whether or not there was conformance with the gateway sequence. Evidence supporting ‘causal linkages between stages,’ as specified by the gateway hypothesis, was not obtained. Nor were specific risk factors identified that were related to consumption of each drug. Our results indicate that efforts to prevent marijuana use should utilize strategies directed at averting the development of the characteristics prodromal to the manifestation of behavior problems.”

Source: Tarter, Ralph E., PhD, Vanyukov, Michael, PhD, Kirisci, Levent, PhD, Reynolds, Maureen, PhD, Clark, Duncan B., MD, PhD, “Predictors of Marijuana Use in Adolescents Before and After Licit Drug Use: Examination of the Gateway Hypothesis,” American Journal of Psychiatry, Vol. 63, No. 12, December 2006, p. 2139.

The Institute of Medicine’s 1999 report on marijuana explained that marijuana has been mistaken for a gateway drug in the past because “Patterns in progression of drug use from adolescence to adulthood are strikingly regular. Because it is the most widely used illicit drug, marijuana is predictably the first illicit drug most people encounter. Not surprisingly, most users of other illicit drugs have used marijuana first. In fact, most drug users begin with alcohol and nicotine before marijuana – usually before they are of legal age.”

Source: Janet E. Joy, Stanley J. Watson, Jr., and John A Benson, Jr., “Marijuana and Medicine: Assessing the Science Base,” Division of Neuroscience and Behavioral Research, Institute of Medicine (Washington, DC: National Academy Press, 1999).

More than 100 million Americans have tried marijuana; 14.4 million Americans are estimated to be “past-month” users. Yet there are only an estimated 2,075,000 “past-month” users of cocaine and 153,000 “past-month” users of heroin.

Source: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, Results from the 2007 National Survey on Drug Use and Health: National Findings (Office of Applied Studies, NSDUH Series H-34, DHHS Publication No. SMA 08-4343), Rockville, MD, Sept. 2008, p. 250, Table G.1, and p. 254, Table G.5.

According to the 2007 National Survey on Drug Use and Health:
“In 2007, the average age at first marijuana use among recent initiates aged 12 to 49 was 17.6 years, which was similar to the average in 2006 (17.4 years) (Figure 5.4). Among recent initiates aged 12 or older who initiated use prior to the age of 21, the mean age at first use was 16.2 years in 2007, which was not significantly different from the estimate (16.1 years) in 2006.”
“In 2007, the average age at first alcohol use among recent initiates aged 12 to 49 was 16.8 years, similar to the corresponding 2006 estimate (16.6 years). The mean age at first use among recent initiates aged 12 or older who initiated use prior to the age of 21 was 15.8 years, which was the same as the 2006 estimate.”
“In 2007, among recent initiates aged 12 to 49, the average age of first cigarette use was 16.9 years, similar to the average in 2006 (17.1 years).”

Source: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, Results from the 2007 National Survey on Drug Use and Health: National Findings (Office of Applied Studies, NSDUH Series H-34, DHHS Publication No. SMA 08-4343), Rockville, MD, Sept. 2008, pp. 52 & 56.

"In 2007, the rate of current illicit drug use was almost 9 times higher among youths aged 12 to 17 who smoked cigarettes in the past month (47.3 percent) than it was among youths who did not smoke cigarettes in the past month (5.4 percent).
“Past month illicit drug use also was associated with the level of past month alcohol use. Among youths aged 12 to 17 in 2007 who were heavy drinkers (i.e., consumed five or more drinks on the same occasion on each of 5 or more days in the past 30 days), 60.1 percent also were current illicit drug users, which was higher than the rate among nondrinkers (5.0 percent).”

Source: Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration, Results from the 2007 National Survey on Drug Use and Health: National Findings (Office of Applied Studies, NSDUH Series H-34, DHHS Publication No. SMA 08-4343), Rockville, MD, Sept. 2008, p. 28.

A study in the Journal of the American Medical Association on cannabis and its possible role as a gateway drug found that “While covariates differed between equations, early regular use of tobacco and alcohol emerged as the 2 factors most consistently associated with later illicit drug use and abuse/dependence. While early regular alcohol use did not emerge as a significant independent predictor of alcohol dependence, this finding should be treated with considerable caution, as our study did not provide an optimal strategy for assessing the effects of early alcohol use.”

Source: Lynskey, Michael T., PhD, et al., “Escalation of Drug Use in Early-Onset Cannabis Users vs Co-twin Controls,” Journal of the American Medical Association, Vol. 289 No. 4, January 22/29, 2003, online at http://jama.ama-assn.org/issues/v289n4/rfull/joc21156.html, last accessed Jan. 31, 2003.

A study in the Journal of the American Medical Association on cannabis and its possible role as a gateway drug concluded that “While the findings of this study indicate that early cannabis use is associated with increased risks of progression to other illicit drug use and drug abuse/dependence, it is not possible to draw strong causal conclusions solely on the basis of the associations shown in this study.”

Source: Lynskey, Michael T., PhD, et al., “Escalation of Drug Use in Early-Onset Cannabis Users vs Co-twin Controls,” Journal of the American Medical Association, Vol. 289 No. 4, January 22/29, 2003, online at http://jama.ama-assn.org/issues/v289n4/rfull/joc21156.html, last accessed Jan. 31, 2003.

"Other mechanisms that might mediate a causal association between early cannabis use and subsequent drug use and drug abuse/dependence include the following:
"1. Initial experiences with cannabis, which are frequently rated as pleasurable, may encourage continued use of cannabis and also broader experimentation.
"2. Seemingly safe early experiences with cannabis may reduce the perceived risk of, and therefore barriers to, the use of other drugs. For example, as the vast majority of those who use cannabis do not experience any legal consequences of their use, such use may act to diminish the strength of legal sanctions against the use of all drugs.
“3. Alternatively, experience with and subsequent access to cannabis use may provide individuals with access to other drugs as they come into contact with drug dealers. This argument provided a strong impetus for the Netherlands to effectively decriminalize cannabis use in an attempt to separate cannabis from the hard drug market. This strategy may have been partially successful as rates of cocaine use among those who have used cannabis are lower in the Netherlands than in the United States.”

Source: Lynskey, Michael T., PhD, et al., “Escalation of Drug Use in Early-Onset Cannabis Users vs Co-twin Controls,” Journal of the American Medical Association, Vol. 289 No. 4, January 22/29, 2003, online at http://jama.ama-assn.org/issues/v289n4/rfull/joc21156.html, last accessed Jan. 31, 2003.

In 2002 the English government published research on the initiation of drug use and criminal offending by young people in Britain. According to the study, “After applying these methods, there is very little remaining evidence of any causal gateway effect. For example, even if soft/medium drugs (cannabis, amphetamines, LSD, magic mushrooms, amyl nitrite) could somehow be abolished completely, the true causal link with hard drugs (crack, heroin, methadone) is found to be very small. For the sort of reduction in soft drug use that might be achievable in practice, the predicted causal effect on the demand for hard drugs would be negligible. Although there is stronger evidence of a gateway between soft drugs and ecstasy/cocaine, it remains small for practical purposes. My interpretation of the results of this study is that true gateway effects are probably very small and that the association between soft and hard drugs found in survey data is largely the result of our inability to observe all the personal characteristics underlying individual drug use. From this viewpoint, the decision to reclassify cannabis seems unlikely to have damaging future consequences.”

Source: Pudney, Stephen, “Home Office Research Study 253: The road to ruin? Sequences of initiation into drug use and offending by young people in Britain” (London, England: Home Office Research, Development, and Statistics Directorate, December 2002), p. vi.

The World Health Organization’s investigation into the gateway effect of marijuana stated emphatically that the theory that marijuana use by adolescents leads to heroin use is the least likely of all hypotheses.

Source: Hall, W., Room, R. & Bondy, S., WHO Project on Health Implications of Cannabis Use: A Comparative Appraisal of the Health and Psychological Consequences of Alcohol, Cannabis, Nicotine and Opiate Use, August 28, 1995 (Geneva, Switzerland: World Health Organization, March 1998).

According to CASA (National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse), there is no proof that a causal relationship exists between cigarettes, alcohol, marijuana and other drugs. Basic scientific and clinical research establishing causality does not exist.

Source: Merrill, J.C. & Fox, K.S., Cigarettes, Alcohol, Marijuana: Gateways to Illicit Drug Use, Introduction (New York, NY: National Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse at Columbia University, October 1994).

The World Health Organization noted the effects of prohibition in its March 1998 study, when it stated that “exposure to other drugs when purchasing cannabis on the black market, increases the opportunity to use other illicit drugs.”

Source: Hall, W., Room, R. & Bondy, S., WHO Project on Health Implications of Cannabis Use: A Comparative Appraisal of the Health and Psychological Consequences of Alcohol, Cannabis, Nicotine and Opiate Use, August 28, 1995 (Geneva, Switzerland: World Health Organization, March 1998).

In March 1999, the Institute of Medicine issued a report on various aspects of marijuana, including the so-called Gateway Theory (the theory that using marijuana leads people to use harder drugs like cocaine and heroin). The IOM stated: “There is no conclusive evidence that the drug effects of marijuana are causally linked to the subsequent abuse of other illicit drugs.”

Source: Janet E. Joy, Stanley J. Watson, Jr., and John A Benson, Jr., “Marijuana and Medicine: Assessing the Science Base,” Division of Neuroscience and Behavioral Research, Institute of Medicine (Washington, DC: National Academy Press, 1999).

The Institute of Medicine’s 1999 report on marijuana explained that marijuana has been mistaken for a gateway drug in the past because “Patterns in progression of drug use from adolescence to adulthood are strikingly regular. Because it is the most widely used illicit drug, marijuana is predictably the first illicit drug most people encounter. Not surprisingly, most users of other illicit drugs have used marijuana first. In fact, most drug users begin with alcohol and nicotine before marijuana, usually before they are of legal age.”

Source: Janet E. Joy, Stanley J. Watson, Jr., and John A Benson, Jr., “Marijuana and Medicine: Assessing the Science Base,” Division of Neuroscience and Behavioral Research, Institute of Medicine (Washington, DC: National Academy Press, 1999).

Read full topic

@Ollie wrote:

[quote=“jme, post:20, topic:262441”][quote author=bowserjr2 link=topic=346575.msg2673046#msg2673046 date=1234906605]
One problem with it is people that use it easy go over on harder things like LSD and Heroin.
[/quote]

No it doesn’t. That’s like saying drinking coffee makes you try harder drugs like meth.[/quote]

No he is right, smoking weed is an entry to harder drugs, it is a proven fact(something like 90% try harder drugs after weed)!

But really, alcohol is the entry drug…
